Title: Is Ukraine Pushing Biden Toward a Second Term?
Narrative:
It's a question that Biden and his press secretary are frequently asked, and the answer is always the same: "yes." Even if the 79-year-old Biden was secretly planned to leave after one term, announcing it now would be political malpractice, as Susan Milligan points out, since it would render him an early lame duck with significantly lower political capital. 

However, according to US News Biden usually avoids going into detail about the subject, instead dismissing it with a fast affirmative and a request for the next question. 

When questioned about European concerns that the work Biden and friends had done on the Russia-Ukraine situation could be undone in a couple of years, Biden speculated candidly about what was at risk.

“I've been dealing with foreign policy for longer than anybody who's been involved in the process right now," Biden said at a press conference in Brussels, responding to a question from a reporter from the German news magazine Der Spiegel. Biden added, "I don't think you'll find any European leader who thinks that I am not up to the task."

Biden began talking about the turning point for him ahead of the 2020 campaign after spending the day meeting with NATO and G-7 allies and formulating a proposal for harsher sanctions on Russia and greater humanitarian aid for Ukraine and countries hosting refugees. 

Biden claimed he had no intention of running for president a third time, repeating a storey he has repeated many times. But then he saw the Charlottesville white nationalist demonstration and march – and then-President Donald Trump's reaction – and he changed his mind.
